metadata.title: Lady tasting tea: A Bayesian approach | by Alireza Modirshanechi | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Lady tasting tea: A Bayesian approach
metadata.description: A lady claims that she can find out whether tea or milk is added first to a cup of milk tea, only by tasting it. How can we evaluate her claim? Through solving this problem, known as the lady tasting…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: “The Bayesian information criterion: background, derivation, and applications”

all_paragraphs: A lady claims that she can find out whether tea or milk is added first to a cup of milk tea, only by tasting it. How can we evaluate her claim? Through solving this problem, known as the lady tasting tea problem, Sir Ronald Fisher introduced the notions of hypothesis testing and p-value for the first time.
In this article, I revisit Fisher's solution (i.e. the frequentist approach), use a Bayesian approach for the problem of lady tasting tea, and compare their results.

Given a cup of milk tea, we assume that the lady would guess the right answer (i.e. whether tea or milk is added first) with the probability p. If she guesses randomly, we expect that p is equal to 0.5 — i.e. what is called the chance level. If she has some magical skill, then we expect to find a probability greater than 0.5.

Therefore, to decide whether she lies or not, we should test whether p=0.5 (called the null hypothesis and shown usually by H₀ or M₀) or p>0.5 (called the alternative hypothesis and shown by H₁ or M₁). To do so, we ask her to taste N cups of milk tea and tell us her guesses. We denote the number of her right guesses by n.
Now the question is: How can we use this information (i.e. n and N) to decide whether she lies or not?

The frequentist approach for testing the null hypothesis is based on the computation of p-values¹. For the case of the lady tasting tea, the p-value is the probability of the cases with more than or equal to n right guesses out of N cups given the assumptions that the lady has lied about her abilities. If this probability is very small, then it is hard to believe that she could make these many right choices only due to pure chance. Therefore, we will reject the null hypothesis for the cases with very small p-values².

So, how small the p-value is would be the criterion for accepting the lady's claim (i.e. the alternative hypothesis, M₁). There are some traditional thresholds for rejecting the null hypothesis. A summarisation³ can be found in the table below.
Now the question is: How should we compute p-values?
For an arbitrary p, the probability of having m right guesses out of N guesses is
Given the null hypothesis, we have p=0.5, and hence, we can compute the p-value as

As N increases, the distribution of having m right guesses converges to a Gaussian distribution with the mean Np and the variance Np(1-p) — according to the central limit theorem⁴. Then, the p-value can be approximated by⁵
where the 2nd term is the cumulative density function (cdf) of a Gaussian distribution at the value n, with the mean N/2 and the variance N/4.

From the Bayesian perspective, the null and alternative hypotheses can be seen as two different models M₀ and M₁, respectively, which are candidates for generating data. Then, Bayesian hypothesis testing is equivalent to the Bayesian model selection: Which model explains data better?

The idea in Bayesian model selection is to compute the posterior probability of each model given the observed data, e.g. P(M₀|n) in our setting. The odd posterior ratio is defined as the ratio of two posterior probabilities as

where the 1st term on the right side is called the odd prior ratio and the 2nd term is called "Bayes factor"⁶. If there is no prior preference between two models (i.e. when we have uniform prior over the models), the odd posterior ratio is equal to the Bayes factor.

Bayes factor is the central concept in Bayesian hypothesis testing and model selection⁷. High values of the Bayes factor tell us that the alternative model is much more probable than the null model, given the observations. So, how large the Bayes factor is would be the criterion for accepting the lady’s claim (i.e. the alternative hypothesis, M₁). Similar to the case of p-values, there are some traditional thresholds for rejecting the null hypothesis, summarised in Table 1³.
Now the question is: How should we compute the Bayes factor?

For the problem of lady tasting tea, each model can be characterized by a prior distribution over the probability of a single right guess p. The characterization of the null model is straightforward and without any ambiguity: p is equal to 0.5 — the prior is a delta distribution at 0.5. As a result, the conditional probability P(n|M₀) can be computed easily using the formulas mentioned in the previous section.

However, the characterization of the alternative model M₁ is not trivial. We know that the prior distribution must have its whole mass on p>0.5, but we need to specify exactly the form of the prior — it is necessary for the computation of P(n|M₁). Then, what is a good choice of prior?
One very simple but intuitive choice of prior is a uniform distribution over the interval of [0.5,1]. Using this prior, the log Bayes factor can be computed as

It can be shown that⁸ if the prior distribution is non-zero in a neighborhood of the maximum likelihood (ML) estimate of the parameter p, then, as N increases, the log conditional probability log(P(n|M₁)) can be estimated by (a constant times⁹) Bayesian information criterion (BIC). It is surprising but true that as N increases, the effect of the prior disappears. Therefore, for large N, the Bayes factor can be approximated (whenever n>N/2) by
When n≤N/2, we have logBF(n)≈-log(N)/2, but it might not be an accurate approximation anymore, because the ML estimate of p is out of the prior's support — is less than 0.5.

For different choices of N and n, we computed both the exact and approximated p-value and Bayes factor. Then, for each level of significance, according to Table 1, we computed the critical ratio of right guesses (i.e. n/N) above which we reject the null hypothesis. The boundaries for 4 different levels of "borderline", "moderate", "strong", and "very strong" are shown in Fig. 1.
There are a few interesting take-home messages:

In contrast to the frequentist approach, the Bayesian approach for hypothesis testing can make statements also about accepting the null hypothesis. The logic is the same, we just need to look at the negative log Bayes factor. A set of similar critical ratios of right guesses below which we will accept the null hypothesis (that the lady has lied) can be found. The boundaries are shown in Fig. 2.
The result can be summarised in three points:
We studied hypothesis testing from both Bayesian and frequentist perspectives for the particular example of lady tasting tea. Three general conclusions are:
I am grateful to Navid Ardeshir, Kian Kalhor, Mohammad Tinati, and Parnian Kassraie for many useful and interesting discussions on related topics in the past few years.
The code (in Julia language) for the analyses can be found here.
¹ See chapter 7 of "Statistical Models" by A. C. Davison or chapter 10 of "All of Statistics" by L. Wasserman for further study about hypothesis testing from frequentist points of view.
² It is worth mentioning that the frequentist approach to hypothesis testing aims only to reject the null hypothesis, and it cannot make any statement about accepting it.
³ The table is made by combining the information from “Computer Age Statistical Inference” by B. Efron and T. Hastie and "On p-Values and Bayes Factors" by L. Held and M. Ott.
⁴ m can be seen as the output of summing the value of N Bernoulli random variables with the probability p for being 1. Hence, for large N, its distribution converges to a Gaussian distribution.
⁵ This is equivalent to using a one-sample t-test over these N trials.
⁶ A curious reader can think about the relations between Bayes factor and likelihood ratio in Neyman–Pearson lemma.

⁷ See the amazing article “The Bayesian information criterion: background, derivation, and applications” by A. Neath and J. Cavanaugh and chapter 13 of “Computer Age Statistical Inference” by B. Efron and T. Hastie for further study.

⁸ See chapter 13 of “Computer Age Statistical Inference” by B. Efron and T. Hastie for an introduction to Bayesian model selection, and Rouder, et al. (2009) and Rouder, et al. (2012) for Bayesian alternatives of t-test and regression test.

⁹ The constant depends on the definition of BIC. If we take the definition mentioned in “Computer Age Statistical Inference”, the constant is 1, but if we take the definition in Wikipedia, we need the constant to be -0.5.

I found this song a few weeks ago. It is pretty cute and funny, while deeply dark and sad. I really like it, so I decided to exploit the fact that its cover shows two ladies drinking tea (coffee?) and put its link at the end of this article!
